Will, as promised, we had that two-week challenge.
Remind us what it is.
Sure.
Take a seven-by-seven square grid.
Arrange the names of U.S.
cities or towns in regular crossword fashion inside the grid so that the cities used have the highest possible total population according to the 2010 Census.
For example, if you put Chicago in the top row and Houston in the sixth row, both reading across, and then fit Atlanta, Oakland and Reno coming down, you'll form a mini-crossword.
And the five cities used have a total population, according to the 2010 Census, of 5,830,997.
You can do better.
As in a regular crossword, the names must read across and down only.
Every name must interlock with at least one other name.
And no two letters can touch unless they are part of a name.
What is the highest population total you can achieve?
And please include the names of the cities, in order, across and down with your answer.
When you've got the answer, go to our website, npr.org/puzzle and click on the Submit Your Answer link - just one entry per person, please.
And we're in week two of this challenge, so our deadline for entries is this Thursday, October 24th at 3 P.M. Eastern Time.
Please include a phone number where we can reach you at about that time.
And if you're the winner we will give you a call, and you'll get to play on the air with the puzzle editor of The New York Times and WEEKEND EDITION's puzzle-master, Will Shortz.
Thanks so much, Will.
Thanks, Rachel.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
This is NEWS AND NOTES, I'm Ed Gordon.
On today's ROUNDTABLE, President Bush vows that Iraqi troops will be in control of their country by the end of year and ready or not, here it comes, the bird flu.
from our New York Bureau, John McWhorter, Manhattan Institute senior fellow on Public Policy.
E.R.
Shipp also joins us.
She is professor of journalism at Hofstra University and she joins us from the campus there in Hempstead, New York.
And Glen Loury, professor of economics at Brown University joins us from member station WRNI in Providence, Rhode Island.
All right folks, here is something that clearly people were looking to hear.
And I was surprised, John McWhorter, that I did not hear more about this in the news, quite frankly.
For the first time this week the President announced that he expects to turn over most of Iraq to what he deemed the newly trained Iraqi troops by the end of this year, a timetable if you will.
This is something that people have been asking about.
Again, not the kind of hoopla that I thought would surround this announcement.
Well what's interesting is this is really seismic because for the Bush Administration to say something like this, which clearly isn't true.
I mean, the Iraqi troops are not going to be ready in anything like that time, shows that they are actually having to acknowledge that something is terribly wrong in Iraq at this point.

It's really just a kind of posturing because that's not going to happen by December or, if you ask me, the December after that, but it means that things have gotten so clearly bad, it's not almost a civil war in Iraq right now, it is a civil war depending on what you call it.
That we're seeing that something is about to turn around.
Even the administration is aware that something needs to be done.
E.R.
Shipp, the president acknowledged developments on the ground as being grim in his words, but declared real progress in standing up for Iraqi forces and defending the nation.
It was quietly, again, quietly announced in a speech by the president.
it was not delivered with the same hoopla that one might expect.
Is this and does this speak to what John is suggesting that the White House doesn't totally believe that this is going to work?
Ms.
E.R.
SHIPP (Journalism Professor, Hofstra University): I think that's very true.
If 65 percent of Americans say that the president has no real plan for getting us out of the Iraqi quagmire, then he has to do something.
And maybe what he's doing is dreaming.
I would sing the song, but I won't.
It's (singing) Dream...
I knew you were going to...
(Soundbite of laughter)

So he has to say something, but he says it in a low-key manner knowing that policy wants such as ourselves will pick up on it and broadcast it to the world that he is thinking about a timetable, but as John says, December 31 does not sound feasible at all to think that the Iraqi troops will be able to take over most of the country.
We don't even know who the Iraqi troops are, we keep getting different numbers on how many of them are trained, how many of them are insurgents who are giving away...
Yeah.
...troop movements.
We have no real sense of control there.
Glen here's the interesting point, as John noted, this probably will not be feasible in assuming that you would literally turn over the country to these troops.
Why would a White House that continues of late stumble, make a statement like this.
Is it desperation as John suggested?
You know it sounds an awful lot like desperation to me.
They have to say something, they're taking a terrible political beating over this and what with all the other things that have gone wrong.

And when you just step back and take the toll of this horrible fiasco, which has been this intervention in Iraq: our Constitution is frayed, our army is overstretched, our reputation in the world has been tarnished.
Xenophobia has been promoted at home.

This has been a disaster and I think they're trying to manage the problem as best they can, but unfortunately, the circumstances on the ground militate in favor of a very negative outcome for us over there.

There's something else that may become problematic for the Bush Administration: we heard from the secretary of Health and Human Services this week, a recommendation that Americans start to store canned tuna, powdered milk and other non-perishables under their bed with the prospect of the deadly bird flu outbreak...
Why under the bed?
